greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest integer b such that n=a^b for some integer a; a(0)=a(1)=1 by convention.
comment: A000005(a(n))-1 yields the number of times n is listed in A072103, i.e., the number of ways it can be written differently as perfect power.
The same as A052409 if the convention is dropped. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jan 29 2015
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
example: For any n, a(n) >= 1 since n = n^1.
Integers n = 0 and n = 1 can be written as n^b with arbitrarily large b; to remain consistent with the preceding formula and the comment, the conventional choice a(n) = 1 seemed the best one.
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 25 2015
